name: Relational Databases and Deployment Options
description: Scenarios to choose between relational database types and AWS deployment methods.

cards.front: A solutions architect needs to recommend a storage solution for frequently changing, temporary data that doesn’t need to persist after instance termination. What is the best fit?
cards.back: Amazon EC2 Instance Store is ideal for ephemeral data that can be lost during instance stops or terminations.
cards.example: Using EC2 Instance Store for temporary cache files or buffers that reset after each instance restart.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: Which Amazon storage service persists data independently of the instance it is attached to, even after shutdown or termination?
cards.back: Amazon EBS provides persistent block storage that is independent of the instance lifecycle.
cards.example: A database volume stored in EBS remains intact after stopping the EC2 instance it is attached to.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: Your company stores data that is rarely accessed but must be retrieved quickly when needed. Which S3 storage class is most appropriate?
cards.back: Amazon S3 Standard-Infrequent Access is designed for data that is infrequently accessed but requires rapid retrieval.
cards.example: Archiving compliance reports that are accessed quarterly fits S3 Standard-IA well.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: Can Amazon EBS volumes be attached to Amazon S3 buckets for storage purposes?
cards.back: No. Amazon EBS volumes can only be attached to Amazon EC2 instances, not to Amazon S3.
cards.example: A developer mistakenly tries to attach an EBS volume to an S3 bucket to back up data.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: Which instance families are supported by Amazon RDS to provide different performance profiles?
cards.back: Amazon RDS supports Standard, Memory Optimized, and Burstable Performance instance families.
cards.example: Using a memory-optimized RDS instance for an in-memory analytics database.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: Which database service is fully managed, serverless, and optimized for high-performance key-value NoSQL workloads?
cards.back: Amazon DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database designed for high-scale key-value access.
cards.example: A game leaderboard service uses DynamoDB to track player scores in real time.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: You're migrating a legacy ERP system to the cloud and need a relational database with minimal changes to the existing schema. Which AWS storage service is best for this use case?
cards.back: A relational database such as Amazon RDS (managed) or a self-managed RDBMS on EC2 is ideal. These support fixed schemas and ACID compliance needed by ERP systems.
cards.example: A retail company lifts and shifts its on-premises Oracle database to AWS using Amazon RDS for Oracle to minimize re-architecture.
cards.mnemonic: ERP = Easy with RDS or Postgres
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: You want full control over database tuning and OS-level configuration while using AWS infrastructure. Which deployment model fits best?
cards.back: Use an unmanaged relational database hosted on Amazon EC2. This provides full control over the OS, database engine, and configurations.
cards.example: A data engineering team installs PostgreSQL on an EC2 instance to control fine-tuned performance parameters.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: You need a relational database for an application with a stable schema and require automatic patching, backup, and high availability. Which AWS option should you choose?
cards.back: Use a managed service like Amazon RDS. It handles provisioning, patching, backups, and HA setup while allowing focus on schema and queries.
cards.example: A startup runs its CRM backend using Amazon RDS for MySQL to reduce operational overhead.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: Your legacy on-premises SQL Server needs to migrate to AWS without giving up granular query tuning and OS-level tools. What's the best deployment method?
cards.back: Host SQL Server on Amazon EC2 to retain full administrative control while leveraging AWS infrastructure.
cards.example: A bank migrates its compliance database to EC2 with SQL Server to maintain precise index tuning.
cards.mnemonic: SQL on EC2 = Still in Charge
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service

cards.front: You’re designing an app that depends on strong consistency and referential integrity across tables. What type of database is the best fit?
cards.back: A relational database is ideal because it enforces ACID compliance and supports structured schemas and joins across tables.
cards.example: An e-commerce platform uses a relational DB to ensure product inventory and orders are always consistent.
cards.subject: Choose the Right Storage Service
